title: Will Dubai's EXPO 2020 attract 25 million visits?
preds: Just shy of 23 million by Sunday close.    It attracted 1 million visits over the weekend.   Weekends in UAE run Friday-Saturday.   Feels like final weekend would be a peak flow attendance, so I don't expect it to attract the requisite 2 million over the last few weekdays. Question closes tomorrow - I think it will be close, but still suspect sub 24.5 million (and would probably guess the final number at around 23.5 million).    Still though, amazing effort by the Emiratis given Covid. https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2022/03/29/expo-2020-dubai-attracts-1-million-visits-in-three-days-with-25-million-target-in-sight/

Nearly 23mln. 
OTOH, “This means the first expo in the region has fulfilled its commitment to attract between 22.9 million and 25.4 million visits, a target set out in the registration dossier officially ratified by Bureau International des Expositions member states in 2015.”
https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2022/03/29/expo-2020-dubai-attracts-1-million-visits-in-three-days-with-25-million-target-in-sight/
Looks like it will be closer than many expected..but no cigar.
Sadly, with under a week left, visitation is still far below 25M.  I will say this has been truly the classiest and architecturally impressive Expo!
The recent update 2 weeks before the end of Expo stated that 20m visitors attended the event.

“Expo 2020 Dubai reached the remarkable milestone of 20 million visits on Saturday — only five million away from its goal of attracting 25 million visits, the Expo News Service announced on March 19.” https://www.khaleejtimes.com/expo/expo-2020-dubai-celebrates-milestone-20-million-visits

OK, Brier buster, I think they got the message about “the last minute surge of about 1.5 million” that I referred to earlier. 
This past week:
“Expo 2020 Dubai continues to draw large crowds as total number of visits surpass $1.5 million in just the past week as reported by The National.”
https://www.brecorder.com/news/amp/40160854 And the source this refers to: https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2022/03/15/expo-2020-dubai-almost-16m-visits-in-one-week-as-numbers-reach-19m/ About 19 million total now.

COVID
War
Flight restrictions
Increasing prices and likely declining world economy.
Feedback effects of the above: some people go because everyone else is going, but if everyone else isn't going... they don't go.

Hmm. Maybe I went down to 0 too soon. Technically, it shouldn’t be possible. A typical week would add 600k-700k new visits. Even with a bit of a spike for the closing ceremony, it’s way short of 25 mln. Also China’s zero-Covid policy and the war in Europe should make international travel moot. Last week, however, they recorded +1.4mln. More interestingly, mentions of the original goal are back. Which makes me think once again that creative incentives plus creative accounting can make it happen. 
“The last minute surge of about 1.5 million visits per week is likely to bring numbers closer to the original 25 million target.”
https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2022/03/08/expo-2020-visitor-numbers-jump-by-1-million-to-cross-17-million-visits/

The usual markets of inbound tourism travel into the UAE include the CIS countries, UK, and increasingly China.  Given both China's Zero Covid Policy and other similar strict measures, the China outbound traveler will not be as prevalent.  With only a month to go, and the ColdPlay concert over (albeit an awesome concert!), the visitor count isn't close to 25M.  Hats off tho to the incredible architecture of pavilions, special events (panels, performances, etc) which brought back repeat domestic visitors.

We're nearing one month until the end of the EXPO, and the total attendee count is nearing 15 million (14,719,277 visitors as of February 21). Without an unprecedented increase, the EXPO will not reach its initial goal of 25 million visits. Source: https://www.msn.com/en-ae/money/news/expo-2020-dubai-receives-close-to-15-million-visitors-as-of-february-21/ar-AAU9yij?;ctype=news++&amp%252525253Bappid=hwbrowser

With less than half the target reached, not likely.
Unless there is a rush on tickets in the next few weeks, it's unlikely that Expo attract 25M visitors.

13.5 million as of 14 February. And that included Prince William's visit, a high-profile celebrity: 
"More than one million visits in one week: Expo 2020 Dubai visits soar to 13.5 million
Visitors have embraced the urgency of the 'Now or never, before it's gone forever' mantra"
https://www.khaleejtimes.com/expo/more-than-one-million-visits-in-one-week-expo-2020-dubai-visits-soar-to-13-5-million

11.6 million as of 31 January. About 8 weeks left. I don’t see the 25-million goal mentioned anywhere (anymore) so extremely unlikely. 20 million would be a nice round number for the organizers. 
NB: “Numbers will be boosted further in the coming weeks by the resumption of Dubai school visits and Expo's Young Stars programme.” 
“Before the suspension of excursions, organisers estimated that around a third of the UAE’s school population had made trips to Expo, with more than 334,000 visits from pupils over the course of 41 school days.”
https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2022/02/01/expo-2020-dubai-visitor-numbers-exceed-11-million-as-school-visits-resume/

Numbers reached 11,608,240 as of January 31st, 2022, but as there are less than two months to go before the end of the Expo, I am lowering my forecast. Numbers would need to more than double in the last two months, and the goal of 25 million visits is not promoted as heavily. Source: https://www.breakingtravelnews.com/news/article/expo-2020-welcomes-11-million-guests-to-date/
Only 10 million visitors so far.  With new COVID strains spreading and Houthi threats looming, there are unlikely to be 15 million visitors in the last 59 days of the event.

Maintaining roughly the same pace per week, which is still insufficient to hit 25 million by end of March:
“Expo 2020 Dubai has recorded 10,836,389 visits as of January 24, while virtual visitation reached 72.5 million.” 
https://gulfbusiness.com/expo-2020-dubai-records-close-to-11-million-visits-as-of-january-24/ Also a reminder, if anyone needs one, February is a short month.
Actual numbers are very low at this point with only 2 + months to go!
New variant slowing down travel plans
25 million is too big a number with the current environment, but the Expo looked amazing from afar.
It's probably not going to happen.
Tracking down with news of 10M milestone reached at about half way.

Well, they keep trying. (But I don’t see any references to the 25mln goal anymore. Instead, the 10mln is a “record.”) “The special price is in celebration of Expo 2020 Dubai’s record of 10 million visits.”
https://gulfnews.com/amp/expo-2020/expo-2020-dubai-one-day-ticket-is-just-dh10-on-sunday-1.84966738
10 millions visitors as of today in mid-January

Here's the progression of visitor numbers (taken from source links from @stephen-scott, @Zauchka) Date	       Visitors	       Increase pw
01/10/2021	 -   	
08/11/2021	 2,942,388 	 542,019 
20/12/2021	 7,167,591 	 704,201 
27/12/2021	 8,067,012 	 899,421 
04/01/2022	 8,958,132 	 779,730  There are ~12 weeks left, to hit 25m there would have to be ~1.3m weekly visitors. i.e. 100% uplift on recent visitors across remaining period.
So, baring big changes, I'd say there's no realistic prospect of hitting 25m. That being said...  the Expo seems quite high profile for Dubai, so wouldn't be surprised if they try to push up numbers a bit to hit original target (more free tickets, extend how long it is running, etc.), so still leaving a few % in yes.

Tracking at over 8 million by end of Dec. 
Way off track, so my prediction is adjusted massively https://www.khaleejtimes.com/expo/expo-2020-dubai-over-8-million-visits-as-event-boosts-covid-19-safety-measures

9 million in the first 3 months—with three more to go. 
https://gulfnews.com/expo-2020/expo-2020-dubai-crosses-half-way-mark-with-almost-9-million-visits-1.84745727 All visitors must be tested (which can be done nearby and is, I believe, free) or show proof of vaccination. I think we all know how that works with omicron.
Growing headwinds and a very high hurdle.

On the one hand, “With strict safety measures, Expo enjoys unprecedented numbers” (said of the 8 mln visits; https://gulfnews.com/amp/opinion/editorials/with-strict-safety-measures-expo-enjoys-unprecedented-numbers-1.84640033).  OTOH, “World's fair in Dubai warns of possible closures over virus” (https://beta.ctvnews.ca/national/world/2021/12/28/1_5720949.html).  The big O wave is here (e.g., “The daily infection toll exceeded 1,840 on Tuesday, the highest in six months.”), which makes it harder to hit the target.

7.1 million as of 20 December. And a follow-up on the dining discussion: 10 people tested positive at an Expo restaurant.  https://www.khaleejtimes.com/expo/expo-2020-dubai-visit-numbers-cross-7-million-mark-as-on-december-20?amp=1 https://amp.france24.com/en/live-news/20211222-dubai-expo-sushi-restaurant-closes-after-staff-catch-covid

I had considered the goal of 25 mln visits as something the organizers’ pride (if nothing else) may be staked on. But this (plus the reasonable excuse of omicron) offers a face-saving stat if the original goal for in-person visits isn’t met:
“Abu Dhabi: Publications and news related to Expo 2020 Dubai quoting the Emirates News Agency (WAM) had reached 9.1 billion views across all platforms worldwide in just two months, from October 1 until November 30, 2021.” 
https://gulfnews.com/amp/expo-2020/news/wams-expo-2020-dubai-related-content-surpasses-9-billion-views-report-1.1639833875383 Also, this initiative doesn’t suggest that visitors are exactly flocking to Expo and its restaurants:
“From 9 December – 7 January simply purchase an Expo 2020 day pass in advance and make a restaurant reservation for the same day on the Expo website. Visitors can then redeem the ticket price from the bill at their chosen outlet.”
https://www.africa.com/dine-by-night-free-entry-to-expo-2020-dubai/
Increasingly unlikely as a result of Omicron
Both omicron and the current number of ~6.3mln as of Dec.13. It can still happen, of course, but more likely than not to stay below the threshold.

https://www.themeparkinsider.com/flume/202112/8657/
Good comparison to theme park attendance.  It cites 5.6 million attendees through first two months (so one-third of total schedule).  A straight multiplication by 3 leaves the total more than 7 million short of the 25 million goal.  That does not preclude a surge in the closing months.  However, this article also points out how many people are traveling from outside the UAE and where they are coming from.  Troubling for the goal is that only 28% of visitors are foreign.  
Other factors that may jolt numbers, but still low probability:
The population of UAE is 10 million - opportunity to increase visits without significant travel.  May require incentives from central government.
Season pass holders - 1.2 million of the total visits so far.  if these are local pass holders, it may amplify domestic attendance impact.  But this means single visits are about 4.6 million, therefore about 25% of attendees are returning.
The numbers that have come in would not reach even 20 million by March if held constant, and with Omicron rising I think odds are low. Especially with the virtual alternative.
Trends are still unfavorable as time passes, so I'm notching down some more.  I'm curious if school classes are being sent multiple times, thus registering multiple visits

Nearly 3 million visitors in the first 5 weeks and so many locals still talking about 'we must go soon'... the numbers will keep climbing, but at what rate? 
So far 12% of the target, in 19% of the time. 
They started encouraging mid-week visits by dropping the prices, they have introduced season tickets and festive tickets - they are trying hard.  The question is:  when the stats start climbing will it be sustained growth or just a bump?

Came to see if anyone has the latest numbers. 
In the news, “Free tickets and a national holiday drew in tens, if not hundreds of thousands of people for the Golden Jubilee celebrations.”
https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/uae-at-50/2021/12/02/crowds-flock-to-expo-2020-dubai-for-national-day-extravaganza/
Trending down considering resurgent of COVID-19 variants likely impacting foreign travel over next 60-120 days.
Numbers aren't moving up fast enough + omicron, so I'm notching down

Omicron Variant likely to dissuade travelers or limit ability for people to get to Dubai by transiting countries with restrictions just as momentum needs to build and get over the early off target attendance numbers.  larger drop in likelihood.

Down again on the “Xi” variant as it would probably increase travel hesitancy, if nothing worse. OTOH, if it fades quickly, Alicia Keys is bound to attract a sizeable audience: 
https://www.timeoutabudhabi.com/news/alicia-keys-expo-2020-dubai As others have stated below, 4.1mln visits over 7 weeks projects to only ~15mln in ~26 weeks *if the growth is linear*
-5 on the chance that the omicron COVID strain lowers attendance over the next few months

As per article in the link, close to 3mm visitors as of November 9th. With the new travel restrictions looming due to a new COVID variant, it is hard to see the totals approaching anywhere close to 25mm.
https://english.alarabiya.net/News/gulf/2021/11/09/Expo-2020-Dubai-Visitor-numbers-approach-three-million-

It's not looking good.  As of 22 Nov, only 4.1 million people have visited in the seven weeks since it opened.   Going on current numbers, and looking at the projected schedule, less than 15 million people are likely to attend.
As in the case of all ventures, they are increasing their push to different demographics.

Another big jump, from 2.3 mln at wk5 to 3.5-smth mln at wk6. Yes, a linear projection would take it to only 15.6 mln or so, but the pace is not uniform (so far) and is characterized by big jumps in the reported figures from week to week. So why should we assume it will be uniform and make no further big jumps from now on? The goal is 25 mln. The motivation to reach it is there.  https://www.breakingtravelnews.com/news/article/expo-2020-welcomes-millions-of-guest-in-first-six-weeks/ “Expo 2020 Dubai has announced its latest visitor numbers, with 3,578,653 individual visits achieved by November’s half-way point, only six weeks into Expo’s six-month run.”

Continuing on similar logic from my last update:  
3.5 million visitors in first six weeks (https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2021/10/11/dubai-latest-updates-tickets-jobs-visit-passport/).  6 weeks is one-quarter of the approximately 24 weeks in 6 months.  So 3.5 million extrapolated from 6 weeks to 24 weeks is 14 million people - well short of 25 million.  
Of the 25 million goal, 21.5 million remain, which averages out to 1.19 million per week for the remaining 18 weeks to reach 25 million.  The current average is .58 million.  1.19 is a little more than double .58, so starting today, attendance has to double and remain at the increased level for 18 week.s  
Unless there are large changes through the holiday/new year season, the original goal is getting further out of reach.  Reducing my estimate significantly.

18 > 27. Upward revisions to the reported data. Odds are still against, but less than they were. Total for first 6 weeks = 3.6 million https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2021/11/15/expo-2020-dubai-records-more-than-35-million-visits-in-first-six-weeks/

Noting a big jump in the reported numbers for October: from ~1.5 mln previously reported to 2.35 mln officially reported and almost 3 mln for the first 5 weeks. This is still short of the goal, but now I see it more likely that more such jumps will follow. Also, from the news and personal communication with a friend in Dubai: the city and UAE at large are actively promoting multiple visits to Expo for the local population, including multiple school and university class trips, company visits, and days off for schoolchildren to visit with their families. Each if those visits counts. This, plus better weather, plus the potential—that I cynically continue to see—for over-reporting could push us over the threshold. 
Links: Expo 2020: Dubai firm gifts free tickets to 2,500 employees 
https://www.khaleejtimes.com/expo/expo-2020-dubai-firm-gifts-2500-free-tickets-to-employees Expo 2020 Dubai: Nearly 3 million visits recorded since October 1
https://www.khaleejtimes.com/expo/expo-2020-dubai-nearly-3-million-visits-recorded-since-october-1
“According to Expo 2020 Dubai, 2.35 million visits were recorded in the first month and nearly three million in the first five weeks. The six-month-long mega show will conclude on March 31, 2022.” https://www.khaleejtimes.com/expo/expo-2020-dubai-9-year-old-boy-visits-all-192-country-pavilions Expo 2020 Dubai latest visit figure approaches 3mn
https://timesofoman.com/article/109098-expo-2020-dubai-latest-visit-figure-approaches-3mn

There is an increase in the numbers of people travelling in to Dubai, but does that number convert to Expo tickets?
Is this metric 25million visitors or visits? 
i.e. I'm buying a season ticket, so will be there multiple times - will each visit be counted, or just my initial purchase? 
I believe 25 million visits is more likely than 25 million visitors.   I'm basing my adjustment on the wording of the question - VISITS, not visitors.

I am unsure how transparent the final data will be, but currently, this is not close to being on track to hit 25 million, and I don't foresee attendance rates skyrocketing enough for this to change (even with the pandemic fading in parts of the world and holiday season coming up).  The article at the bottom of my comment has ambiguous wording, but it says:  "Relying on a projection of 25 million visitors, auditors EY in 2019 estimated a $6 billion boost during the event. EY told The Associated Press it hadn’t updated any of its figures and Expo officials now say they expect some 25 million 'visits' both in person and online." I assume this means 25 million, once you add online visits, as opposed to 25 million in-person visits and 25 million online visits.  I'm forecasting 15% to account for the chance this suddenly becomes a top in-demand travel experience for people over the next several months or the chance that data is adjusted in order to make the event seem more successful (not a likely situation, but there is certainly an incentive to do this). If numbers significantly increase over the holiday season, I will adjust my forecast accordingly. Link to article: https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-business-entertainment-dubai-middle-east-ffd6c4502d76a3bfc4d9cc3c5bd6f23c

2.35 million visitors in the first month of operation (https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2021/10/11/dubai-latest-updates-tickets-jobs-visit-passport/).  assuming equal distribution across the 6 months, that's only 14.1 million total.  However, the same page reported 400k in the first 10 days, so that's 1.15 million delta between total for Oct actual from extrapolating the first 10 days across the entire month (400k x 3).  I do not assume that such a positive delta will continue across 6 months.  It will be helpful to recheck November numbers to see how later months attendance trends  are impacted (i.e. cooler weather, COVID restrictions, travel availability, regional tensions). 
Reaching 25 mil over the remaining 5 months will require an average of 4.53 mil per month (original average was 4.17 mil per month over 6 months).  So each month lower than 4.17 mil pushes up the need for the subsequent month(s).  This drives down my estimate for now.

With the first of the six months practically over, I’m still getting ~9 million, based on ~1.5mln for 1-30 October:
“Saudi Arabia's Expo 2020 pavilion reached the milestone of 500,000 visitors at the weekend – an average of one in three of all who have been to the world's fair so far.”
https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2021/10/31/expo-2020-dubai-saudi-arabias-window-to-the-world-offers-glimpse-of-future-expo/ OTOH, “With cooler weather forecast and balmy weekends fast becoming the norm, Expo 2020 Dubai is getting busier.” https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2021/10/28/busy-weekend-ahead-at-expo-2020-dubai-with-amr-diab-concert-among-highlights/ The other reason I’m not going lower at this time is the possible motivation for UAE to inflate or influence the numbers a bit to reach their stated goal of 25 mln. UAE total population is close to 10 million. That’s only 2.5 visits per person to reach the goal.

Coming down a bit, but can't go lower at this time due to scope and we have yet to have the western holiday season where I feel traveling to Dubai to check the Expo and do a dit of duty-free holiday shopping could be on the cards.

'“A total of 1,471,314 visits were recorded in the first 24 days since the Expo opened,” said Sconaid McGeachin, the senior vice president of communications Expo 2020 Dubai.' https://www.khaleejtimes.com/uae/expo-2020-dubai/expo-2020-dubai-nearly-15-million-visits-recorded-in-24-days At that rate, the total *visits* will be ~10 million. And looks like ~2 visits per *visitor* based on Ztest's data point.

I am starting low for initial forecast.
10/19/2021: 20 days in and so far only 750,000 total visitors (https://gulfnews.com/expo-2020/pavilions/italy-pavilion-seen-so-far-by-20-per-cent-of-total-expo-2020-dubai-visitors-1.1634641276347)
Maybe in November and December the number of visitors will pick as Europeans head toward warmer destination for leisure/business travel.

The recent numbers indicate that the visits are up slightly, but trending far below the numbers needed to reach the 25 million threshold. However, we're still less than a month into the EXPO. I have lowered my prediction, but will see how numbers look with better weather and after the upcoming holidays.
It is still averaging about 35-40 degrees peak heat everyday in Dubai, many people are waiting until the weather is a bit more tolerable to visit the EXPO. The numbers will climb up quickly.
The government made initiatives of encouraging the governmental sector employees across the UAE, ease of Visa, tickets offers

The difficulty with this question I found at a first glance last week is that some articles seem to conflate the terms "visitors" and "visits". The question asks about "visits," i.e. the same visitor could visit several times and each visit will be counted toward the 25 mln goal. 
More recent articles seem to clarify this. In particular: 
“More than 700,000 visits to Expo 2020 Dubai since October 1” 
“From October 1 to 17, a total of 771,477 ticketed visits were recorded. Visit numbers have risen by 12 per cent in a week.”
“More than 53,000 visitors flooded through the entrance gates on the first day of Expo.”
https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2021/10/18/more-than-700000-visits-to-expo-2020-dubai-since-october-1/  If we make a simple linear projection, 45,381/day * 182 days = 8,259,342, way below 25 million. (I don't expect it to rise 12% every week!) Canada: "There were 411,000 visits, including repeat visits, in the first 10 days of Expo from 175 countries, according to officials, with one-third of those being tourists." https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/expo-world-fair-relevant-1.6212573  OTOH, Peru: "The Peru Pavilion [...]. In just the first two weeks since opening its doors it received more than 60,000 visitors." (Not sure if visitors = visits here)
https://financialpost.com/pmn/press-releases-pmn/business-wire-news-releases-pmn/peru-holds-a-ribbon-cutting-ceremony-at-its-pavilion-at-dubai-expo-and-wins-4-world-travel-awards  Looking at reporting from past Expos, the figure seems to be generally reported as "visitors." Again, not sure if this includes or excludes repeat visitors, but FWIW: 1. Shanghai 2010 attracted 73 mln visitors: “The World Expo 2010 in Shanghai closed with parades and performances on Sunday after a record 73 million visitors had visited the exhibition in six months.” https://www.english-online.at/news-articles/world/asia/shanghai-expo-sets-new-visitor-record.htm 2. Meanwhile, Milan 2015 reportedly had 21.5 mln visitors—and that’s Milan: an easy stop for anyone in Europe, and not during a pandemic.  In other words, current progress doesn't look promising for reaching 25 million. Even if visits do tick up a bit during the more pleasant season, as @aball25 suggests, and for the closing ceremony, of course, it's a long way to that threshold.

Ticking my forecast back up because in looking at the latest article on visit trends ("From October 1 to 17, a total of 771,477 ticketed visits were recorded, Expo officials announced at the daily briefing on October 18." https://www.khaleejtimes.com/uae/expo-2020-dubai/expo-2020-dubai-over-750000-ticketed-visits-recorded-since-opening) it mentions that the weather has been very hot so far this month -- even preventing schoolchildren from visiting, etc. Looking at yearly weather in Dubai it seems like Nov, Dec, Jan, Feb, and Mar will see much more pleasant weather and the current visit trends may well tick up a good bit. (https://weather-and-climate.com/average-monthly-Rainfall-Temperature-Sunshine-fahrenheit,dubai-ae,United-Arab-Emirates)

https://www.gulftoday.ae/business/2021/10/19/significant-growth--in-attendance Understanding the 750k-770k numbers being visits "One of five visitors of Expo 2020 Dubai since its launch last October, have crossed the entrance of the Italian Pavilion, exploring the exhibition itinerary and participating in dozens of events. Of the 750,000 total visitors to Expo about 150,000 made it to the Italian Pavilion – one of the most sought after among the national ones with a peak of over 30,000 in one of the month’s weekends. In addition to them, over 3 million users were involved in the initiatives of the Pavilion through its website and social channels. In particular, on LinkedIn the Italian Pavilion ranks as first among the 190 of Expo Dubai for the number of followers, with a growth of almost 20% in the last month. With over 40 thousand followers and a monthly growth of 37%, the Pavilion’s Facebook page is the third most visited among those of all the countries participating in Expo. In addition to the visits to the Pavilion, thousands of people filled the arenas of Expo for high-profile musical events that Italy brought to Dubai, including the concert of the Orchestra del Maggio Fiorentino directed by Maestro Zubin Mehta and that of the internationally renowned pianist Ludovico Einaudi as well as just last night the young virtuosos of the National Symphony Orchestra of the Italian Conservatories.    According to major tour operators operating in both Italy and the United Arab Emirates, the monthly volume of bookings of hotels and flights to Dubai has seen increases of up to 40% compared to the same period in 2019, the last comparable year before the Covid-19 pandemic. They also expect a significant growth in attendance in November and December, during holiday breaks in Italy and the rest of Europe. Meanwhile, Master-developer Dubai South Properties announced the launch of ‘The Avenue,’ a limited number of freehold plots which can be purchased on a payment plan and developed by investors for commercial use. The new launch follows the vast development of Dubai South, the successful sell-out of several freehold projects as well as sales of residential plots at the Residential District that were launched earlier by the company. A spokesperson from the master developer Dubai South Properties said: “Following the successful sell-out of other mixed-use developments that we had launched over the last few years, and the surge in demand from investors on both residential and commercial properties, we decided to launch The Avenue, hence create an exceptional opportunity for those who are considering owning their private commercial land for their various business needs. We are also confident that Expo 2020 will play a pivotal role in attracting investors, who will be keen to explore investment opportunities in Dubai. We at Dubai South Properties are committed to cater to the aspirations of potential and existing clientele as well as support the government’s initiatives and plans in attracting foreign direct investments to the emirate.”
Current pace is for 7-8 million, however I have know idea how many special/big events will remain in the future.
I still think there will be an increase in attendance.

Going down a good bit based on this latest article published today (18 Oct)... "Expo 2020 Dubai has welcomed 771,477 ticketed visitors through its gates since its October 1st opening. At roughly 50,000 guests a day, the event is on track to welcome around nine million visitors over its six-month run time" (https://www.breakingtravelnews.com/news/article/expo-2020-dubai-on-track-for-nine-million-visitors/)

"From October 1 to 17, a total of 771,477 ticketed visits were recorded, Expo officials announced at the daily briefing on October 18." (https://www.khaleejtimes.com/uae/expo-2020-dubai/expo-2020-dubai-over-750000-ticketed-visits-recorded-since-opening) --> 771,477/17 = 45,381 per day. Expo will be open for 181 days; 181 x 45,381 = 8.2 million.   So far, significantly off track for 25 million.   33% --> 20%

Decreasing a bit due to report of 411,768 ticketed visits in the first 10 days (source: https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2021/10/11/more-than-400000-people-visit-expo-2020-dubai-in-first-10-days/). Will watch and see how the numbers trend.
On current reported numbers this figure appears impossible to achieve, unless there is a significant increase in the December / January period

The latest numbers give a good indicator for a starting point. Having more than 400,000 visits in the first 10 days can give us a projection of the numbers we could expect, however, I don't think that it will grow linearly as there are other elements that come to play, such as the weather getting cooler, government incentives for employees to visit Expo 2020 and other organizational and individual efforts to encourage people and their families to visit Expo, which act as contributors for the rate to go higher than 400,000 visit as an average for 10 days. Press is reporting ca. 412k visits in first ten days. Assuming 41.2k visits per day x 181 days of Expo = 7.5 million total visits. Obviously, we'll need to update frequently....

routine tourism:  15.9 mil in 2018 with apps 1 mil more each year since 2010 - so eliminating 2020, visitors without expo could be expected around 18 mil (assuming instant rebound to pre-COVID trends).  
Organizers predict: 11 mil Emiratis and 14 mil international visitors (Forbes magazine).    
Past expos with high attendance benefitted from "nearby" travelers who might drive to event.  Dubai is not so easily reached by "neighbors" yet can't be discounted. 10th highest attendance was 31 mil, so 25 mil is a modest goal.
COVID reduction in travelers: People may not want to risk traveling.  However, there is likely 
COVID requirements to enter/freely move: must have test to enter, must wear mask.
One site said the 25 mil goal will count re-visits and virtual visitors.  Since GJO will not count virtual visitors, that makes achieving the mark much more difficult.

Decomposed attendees into domestic & international and then further into a) are interested in attending and b) have means to attend and then backed into how many international visitors would be required to hit target attendance.  Given the base number of annual visitors to Dubai, it seems unlikely that they will hit the bogey during a pandemic.  This assumes 1 person = 1 visit -- if it turns out that the same person can account for multiple visits then this will be revised.
Day 1 was on Friday, I'm starting reasonably strong...but will increase (or decrease) if I need to.

The previous world expo (Milan 2015 attracted 21 million visitors; its goal was 20 million).  Dubai possesses the lodging, restaurants, and other facilities required to support 25 million visitors; however, ongoing concerns and travel restrictions due to COVID currently make it unlikely for Dubai to reach its goal.  If travel restrictions loosen, the probability will increase.

The average visitors of the past 5 years were 15 M considering that this average was in the stable situation, it quite difficult to reach 25M based on the current situation.

Decided to look up Disney World attendance rates to see how they're trending this year compared with the last few. Of course not a direct correlate as Expo is a totally different event in a different part of the world but wanted to get a sense of how many millions of people are passing through turnstiles now compared with the recent past. 43m in 2020, compared with 155m in 2019. https://disneynews.us/disney-parks-attendance/. Back of envelope based on average daily attendance in 2021 shows 58m YTD, but that probably has to do with capacity limits. So in 2021 over 9 months Disney saw 58m, possible that over 6 months Expo could see 25m visits since it's a unique event?

The number of people will depend heavily on the Covid pandemic, and its variants.  In turn, this depends on the availability of good vaccines and the willingness of people to take them.  If EXPO 2020 imposes a mandate for full vaccination, this may reduce the number of people willing to attend.

How is this measured - unique visitors, or the number of entries? 
If unique visitors then it's Not likely.
However, given that there are wee/month and season tickets, a single visitor might enter 10s of times, which may push the numbers up.
Unlikely if we are talking of unique visitors only. However, UAE will be marketing it heavily and will probably offer further inducements to encourage more visits.

Is it number of individual people or visit, i.e. Do multiple visits by the same person count? I don’t think that many people from abroad will come just for EXPO. Therefore, every resident would need to go at least once plus 15m visitors. So, highly unlikely. Although I’m planning to go 20-20 times.  I only give 10% in case of some counting tricks. We know that it has to be a success.
Due to different conflicts in the middle east as well as still Corona impact, the chance to reach 25 mm is low.

According to Reuters, “officials have stuck to a pre-pandemic target of 25 million total visitors to pass through the gates of the Expo, more than twice the size of the United Arab Emirates' roughly 10 million population.” For comparison, the previous Expo in Milan in 2015 attracted 21.5 million visitors. Noting that we’re looking at the number of visitors coming through the gates (per visit) not unique visitors, this is an average of 4.17 million visits per month of the Expo.  The event will require visitors to be vaccinated or have a negative COVID test, but the UAE recently eased some of their mask rules. Lastly, promotions like the complimentary pass to the Expo for guests flying on Emirates, may help increase visitors. The CEO of the Dubai Airports said "we are gearing up for a massive in-rush of visitors to the United Arab Emirates in the next couple of months." Sources:

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-08-11/dubai-airports-sees-rise-in-traffic-after-41-first-half-drop

I believe they will attract more than what is being expected, it is true that COVID-19 has restricted travel but UAE has opened Travel for all around the world. Additionally, some countries are having overly high restrictions but UAE and Dubai have safety precautious measurements along with leadership's involvement in handling covid-19 situation. Hence, most of people would love to see what innovations will be discovered for the human being, and most people will have less places to travel in, but Dubai is open as a country will attract most of the tourists and companies to have open life along with high level of health and medical infrastructure.

Before COVID-19, in 2017, the UAE expected at least 25 million visitors with 70% of those coming from abroad [1]. In order to meet that number in a post COVID world, the UAE has taken a number of steps to encourage people to visit the Expo, to include loosening face mask restrictions in public [2], including access for the entire month of October for the cost of a single days ticket that costs dh95 ($25.86 USD) [3], and offering free PRC testing to non-vaccinated attendees[4]. Additionally, the UAE is celebrating its Golden Jubilee, which is running from 6 April 2021 to 31 March 2022, and consists of multiple events that are attracting visitors and is expected to attract additional visitors [5]. Further, Britain has relaxed travel restrictions to the UAE and travel between the two countries is expected to increase [6]. Finally, the Dubai airport expects to see a spike in visitors in 2022 due to travel restrictions being lifted between the UK, US, and Saudi Arabia, with 27 million travelers already passing through the airport in 2021 [7]. Obviously, this projection will need to be monitored as the event progresses, but, I assess with a 65% probability that the UAE will be able to attract 25 million visits due to the relaxation of COVID safety protocols, reduction in price for Expo tickets, and increased travel to the UAE. [1] https://www.inparkmagazine.com/expo-2020-dubai-forecasts-70-attendance-from-abroad-can-they-do-it/
[2] https://www.livemint.com/news/world/uae-eases-face-mask-rules-ahead-of-expo-2020-dubai-details-here-11632301028737.html
[3] https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/2021/09/23/expo-2020-dubai-offers-first-month-of-full-access-for-cost-of-daily-ticket/
[4] https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/expo-2020/2021/09/15/expo-2020-dubai-visitors-must-be-vaccinated-or-pcr-tested-to-enter/
[5] https://gulfnews.com/uae/the-year-of-50-uaes-golden-jubilee-celebrations-officially-begin-on-april-6-1.78364843
[6] https://www.cnbc.com/2021/09/22/uk-to-accept-uae-vaccinated-travelers-after-months-on-red-list.html
[7] https://www.hindustantimes.com/lifestyle/travel/dubai-airports-see-visitors-spike-in-2022-easing-of-covid-19-curbs-boost-travel-101632209962640.html
